## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**User:**
I've been exploring VerusIDs and I have a question. Can IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies launch currencies on Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
No, IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies cannot launch currencies on Verus. Only Native IDs, which are registered directly from a blockchain as the name parent, can launch currencies on that blockchain, including actual independent blockchains on Verus. IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies, however, will still be valuable for other uses, such as revocation and recovery IDs, personalized on-chain and cross-chain addresses, and more.

**User:**
That's good to know. I was also wondering about *.veth gateway IDs. Are they not able to create Ethereum mapped currencies?

**AI Assistant:**
Actually, that's not correct. *.veth gateway IDs will be available for decentralized registration from the Ethereum bridge converter and will be able to create Ethereum mapped currencies. This is an exception to the rule that non-native IDs cannot create currencies.

**User:**
Thanks for the clarification. I've also been playing around with the testnet and I was wondering, if I want to reset my testnet, can I just restart the testnet daemon?

**AI Assistant:**
No, that's not correct. To reset your testnet, you need to make sure Verus is closed, delete the specified directories, and then restart the testnet daemon (or relaunch Verus Desktop, deactivate verustest, and re-add verustest native). Simply restarting the testnet daemon is not enough.
Can IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies launch currencies on Verus?

No, IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies cannot launch currencies on Verus. Only Native IDs, which are registered directly from a blockchain as the name parent, can launch currencies on that blockchain, including actual independent blockchains on Verus. IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies, however, will still be valuable for other uses, such as revocation and recovery IDs, personalized on-chain and cross-chain addresses, and more.

While Native IDs, those registered directly from a blockchain as the name parent, will be able to launch currencies on that blockchain, and if on Verus, actual independent blockchains, IDs issued by fractional or centralized currencies cannot launch currencies, but will still be valuable as revocation and recovery IDs for all other VerusIDs as well as for personalized on-chain and cross-chain addresses with all identity and NFT features, for proofs, for brands, contract binding, on-chain marketplace trading, or login, and will have the ability to cross-prove common ownership with other IDs as well.The exception to non-native IDs creating currencies, is that *.veth gateway IDs will be available for decentralized registration from the Ethereum bridge converter and will be able to create Ethereum mapped currencies. Registration of .veth IDs will be priced at a level to prevent misuse and support bridge liquidity, with all fees besides the 1 VRSC import fee, which goes into the mining and staking fee pool going to the bridge converter liquidity basket.All of these features are currently enabled on the v0.9.2 new testnet. Stay connected on the #pbaas-development channel and participate in the launch at no actual cost as a testnet liquidity provider and get some nice testnet IDs, launch your own currencies, or start your exclusive ID-restricted club, governance group, or business.## Testnet Reset
To reset your testnet make sure Verus is closed (and no testnet daemon running) and delete the following directories, then restart the testnet daemon (or relaunch Verus Desktop, deactivate verustest and re-add verustest native):
Are *.veth gateway IDs not able to create Ethereum mapped currencies?

No, that's incorrect. *.veth gateway IDs will be available for decentralized registration from the Ethereum bridge converter and will be able to create Ethereum mapped currencies. This is an exception to the rule that non-native IDs cannot create currencies.
